Key elements.name: Key elements of the circular economy

framework_elements.name: Self-repair, spare part service
framework_elements.description: Providing DIY repair kits or spare part programmes for enabling self-repair

framework_elements.name: Non-critical materials and inputs
framework_elements.description: Using materials that are not considered critical: http://ec.europa.eu/growth/sectors/raw-materials/specific-interest/critical_sv

framework_elements.name: Knowledge Management
framework_elements.description: Solidify definitions and create frameworks to support the understanding of the circular economy across contexts and maintain cohesive systems of data sharing, processing and storing.

framework_elements.name: Subscription-based services
framework_elements.description: Providing services through a subscription plan with regular payment schemes

framework_elements.name: Stretch the lifetime
framework_elements.description: While resources are in-use, maintain, repair and upgrade them to maximise their lifetime and give them a second life through take back strategies when applicable

framework_elements.name: Circular procurement
framework_elements.description: Putting in place purchasing guidelines for procurement departments and evaluating suppliers on circular economy principles

framework_elements.name: Using closed loop recycled materials
framework_elements.description: Using waste materials that have been processed and recycled to produce new products within the same industry

framework_elements.name: Customer dialogue, marketing
framework_elements.description: Engaging in discussions with customers to educate and raise awareness of the circular economy and explore circular opportunities together

framework_elements.name: Data and insights
framework_elements.description: Employ technologies to gather and analyse data to provide insights on resource use

framework_elements.name: Joint industry ventures, projects, pilots
framework_elements.description: Working together with industry peers to engage in business activities or exploratory projects that advance the circular economy

framework_elements.name: Non-toxic materials and inputs
framework_elements.description: Using materials that are not toxic or hazardous: https://echa.europa.eu/information-on-chemicals

framework_elements.name: Advocacy for circular economy policy
framework_elements.description: Engaging in discussions with government bodies and policymakers to push for regulations that support the circular economy

framework_elements.name: Design for cyclability
framework_elements.description: Designing to enable multiple uses and lifecycles of a product and its materials

framework_elements.name: Maximise lifetime of biological products
framework_elements.description: Ensure that biological products are properly managed and preserved

framework_elements.name: Takeback programmes
framework_elements.description: Takeback and return of products from customers after end-of-use

framework_elements.name: Part recovery
framework_elements.description: Extraction and reuse of parts from end-of-life products for use in new products

framework_elements.name: Crowd-based services
framework_elements.description: Decentralised services that rely on the power of the crowd or the community

framework_elements.name: Dialogue with internal stakeholders
framework_elements.description: Facilitate discussions and meetings between internal team members to identify circular opportunities

framework_elements.name: Electrification
framework_elements.description: Converting fossil fuel based operations to electric

framework_elements.name: Customer / consumer collaboration
framework_elements.description: Engage and guide customers and consumers to ensure circular use of products

framework_elements.name: Closed loop collection
framework_elements.description: Collection programmes that process products and parts for reuse or recycling within the same industry

framework_elements.name: Community collaboration
framework_elements.description: Engage with the local community where facilities or offices are located

framework_elements.name: Renewable energy, fuels
framework_elements.description: Using renewable energy like solar, wind, etc. or renewable fuels like biomass, etc.

framework_elements.name: Design for resource efficiency
framework_elements.description: Designing products so they use as little materials, water, energy, etc. as possible during use

framework_elements.name: Communication and awareness
framework_elements.description: Raise awareness and run information campaigns about  strategies for and impacts of the circular economy in different contexts.

framework_elements.name: Incorporate digital technology
framework_elements.description: Use digital, online platforms and technologies that provide insights to track and optimise resource use, strengthen connections between supply chain actors, and enable the implementation of circular models

framework_elements.name: Refurbishment, remanufacturing, renovation
framework_elements.description: Activities to clean, decorate, and restore products back to working condition for original or new purposes

framework_elements.name: Maximise lifetime of products after use
framework_elements.description: Give products and parts another life after their end-of-use

framework_elements.name: Water efficiency
framework_elements.description: Enacting measures that optimise water use

framework_elements.name: Design for modularity
framework_elements.description: Designing products of multiple parts that can be easily exchanged

framework_elements.name: Product business models
framework_elements.description: Deliver products through business models that ensure maximum value

framework_elements.name: Rethink the business model
framework_elements.description: Consider opportunities to create greater value and align incentives that build on the interaction between products and services

framework_elements.name: Design for durability
framework_elements.description: Designing products that are made to last and to ensure longer use

framework_elements.name: Valorise waste streams - closed loop
framework_elements.description: Reuse, repurpose, and recycle waste streams within the same industry

framework_elements.name: Leasing, rental, pay per use
framework_elements.description: Providing products through leasing, rental, or pay-per-use models instead of sales

framework_elements.name: Sale of exchangeable parts
framework_elements.description: Selling parts of modular products that can be exchanged or replaced

framework_elements.name: Design for product attachment, emotional durability
framework_elements.description: Designing products to increase consumer’s emotional attachment and ensure longer use

framework_elements.name: Customer programmes
framework_elements.description: Specific programmes or initiatives to help customers become more circular

framework_elements.name: Give-back programmes
framework_elements.description: Initiatives with disadvantaged communities, minorities, people distanced from the labour market

framework_elements.name: Online platforms
framework_elements.description: Developing or utilising online platforms to enable circular economy opportunities through information, product or service offering

framework_elements.name: Valorise waste streams - open loop
framework_elements.description: Reuse, repurpose, and recycle waste streams within other industries

framework_elements.name: Government collaboration
framework_elements.description: Engage with the government on circular policies and programmes

framework_elements.name: Reusable, recyclable materials and inputs
framework_elements.description: Using materials that can be easily reused or recycled after use

framework_elements.name: Internal collaboration
framework_elements.description: Engage internally to guide employees and facilitate greater knowledge sharing between internal divisions

framework_elements.name: Design for the future
framework_elements.description: Account for the systems perspective during the design process, to use the right materials, to design for appropriate lifetime and to design for extended future use

framework_elements.name: Own brand second-hand sale
framework_elements.description: Marketplaces or services that enable the second hand sale of own-brand products

framework_elements.name: Cross-industry projects, pilots
framework_elements.description: Working together with stakeholders and parties in other unrelated industries to implement circular economy strategies and opportunities

framework_elements.name: Design for recycling - mono-materials
framework_elements.description: Designing products with a single material type to more easily recycle them after use

framework_elements.name: Maximise lifetime of products in-use
framework_elements.description: Upgrade, repair, and maintenance while in-use

framework_elements.name: Design for disassembly
framework_elements.description: Designing products of multiple parts that can be easily disassembled

framework_elements.name: Training on the circular economy
framework_elements.description: Provide guidance or professional training to educate employees to use circular economy principles

framework_elements.name: Government programmes
framework_elements.description: Participating in government programmes that support and advance the circular economy

framework_elements.name: Regenerative water
framework_elements.description: Replace freshwater with less impactful alternatives and enact water efficiency measures

framework_elements.name: Financial incentives tied to circular economy
framework_elements.description: Integrating circular economy thinking into employee evaluations that are tied to professional compensation

framework_elements.name: Design for physical durability
framework_elements.description: Designing products to resist damage and wear, and serve a long and useful life.

framework_elements.name: Energy recovery from waste
framework_elements.description: Recover waste energy or generate fuels and energy from waste streams

framework_elements.name: Using open loop recycled materials
framework_elements.description: Using waste materials that have been processed and recycled to produce new products within other industries

framework_elements.name: Open loop upcycling
framework_elements.description: Transforming waste products, materials for reuse within other industries

framework_elements.name: Design for repair
framework_elements.description: Designing products so they are able to be easily repaired

framework_elements.name: Energy efficiency
framework_elements.description: Enacting measures that optimise energy use

framework_elements.name: Regenerative materials
framework_elements.description: Utilise bio-based, reusable, non-toxic and non-critical materials

framework_elements.name: Closed loop upcycling
framework_elements.description: Transforming waste products, materials for reuse within the same industry

framework_elements.name: Use waste as a resource
framework_elements.description: Utilise waste streams as a source of secondary resources and recover waste for reuse and recycling

framework_elements.name: Design for minimal waste
framework_elements.description: Designing products so they produce as little waste as possible during production

framework_elements.name: Co-creation
framework_elements.description: Working together with customers to jointly create products fit for them

framework_elements.name: Prioritise regenerative resources
framework_elements.description: Ensure renewable, reusable, non-toxic resources are utilised as materials and energy in an efficient way

framework_elements.name: Guidance, dialogue with industry stakeholders
framework_elements.description: Engaging in discussions with industry stakeholders to share circular economy best practices and push the industry towards greater circularity

framework_elements.name: Processing waste into fuel
framework_elements.description: Processing waste streams into fuels such as biogas, biofuels, pellets, etc.

framework_elements.name: Data analytics, modelling
framework_elements.description: Utilising data and models to to identify, enable and/or implement circular strategies (eg. effective resource use & logistics planning, circular business models & design)

framework_elements.name: Preservation, conservation
framework_elements.description: Preserving and conserving biological products such as food, forests, etc.

framework_elements.name: Second-hand sale, distribution
framework_elements.description: Marketplaces or services that enable the second hand sale of products

framework_elements.name: Sale of durable, long-lasting goods
framework_elements.description: Selling high quality, long-lasting products

framework_elements.name: Internet enabled, connected operations
framework_elements.description: Connecting products and services into the internet of things to identify, enable and/or implement circular strategies (eg. effective resource use & logistics planning, circular business models & design)

framework_elements.name: Design for bio-degradability
framework_elements.description: Designing products that can easily breakdown and degrade in the environment

framework_elements.name: Recovery and reuse of waste energy
framework_elements.description: Recovering and reusing waste heat, gas, etc. for energy

framework_elements.name: Management, enrichment
framework_elements.description: Managing and enriching biological products such as soil, land, etc.

framework_elements.name: Alternative water use
framework_elements.description: Replacing freshwater use with rainwater, fogwater, seawater, etc.

framework_elements.name: Open loop collection
framework_elements.description: Collection programmes that process products and parts for reuse or recycling within other industries

framework_elements.name: Open loop downcycling
framework_elements.description: Transforming waste products into materials and lower value products within other industries

framework_elements.name: Design out waste
framework_elements.description: Designing to reduce waste during production and use

framework_elements.name: Digital platforms
framework_elements.description: Employ online platforms to connect and improve information sharing between stakeholders

framework_elements.name: Generating energy from waste
framework_elements.description: Generating energy from waste through processes such as anaerobic digestion, gasification, incineration, etc.

framework_elements.name: Payment per use
framework_elements.description: Providing services where customers are charged only when they use it

framework_elements.name: Peer-to-peer online marketplaces
framework_elements.description: Developing or utilising online marketplaces to enable the peer-to-peer exchange of products and services

framework_elements.name: Customisation
framework_elements.description: Allowing customers to alter and modify certain features of the product

framework_elements.name: Sale of refillable parts
framework_elements.description: Selling parts of modular products that can be refilled

framework_elements.name: Product upgrade
framework_elements.description: Providing upgrade programmes or upgrade services for products or parts of products

framework_elements.name: Product maintenance, repair
framework_elements.description: Providing repair services or maintenance services for products or parts

framework_elements.name: Alternative bio-based materials and inputs
framework_elements.description: Using bio-based materials such as bioplastics, mushroom-based materials, etc.

framework_elements.name: Team up to create joint value
framework_elements.description: Work together throughout the supply chain, internally within organisations and with the public sector and communities to increase transparency and create joint value

framework_elements.name: Material efficiency
framework_elements.description: Enacting measures that optimise material use such as 3D printing, etc.

framework_elements.name: Regenerative energy
framework_elements.description: Replace energy sources with less impactful alternatives and enact energy efficiency measures

framework_elements.name: Peer to peer sharing
framework_elements.description: Providing products through sharing between consumers, customers, etc.

framework_elements.name: Joint product development
framework_elements.description: Working together with the community and engaging them in the company operations

framework_elements.name: Research and Development
framework_elements.description: Research and facilitate new technological developments to aid the transition to a circular economy.

framework_elements.name: Industry collaboration
framework_elements.description: Industry peers to industry peer collaboration to create joint value and identify synergies

framework_elements.name: Education and Curriculum
framework_elements.description: Integrate principles of circularity into primary, secondary and tertiary curriculum and conduct workplace trainings

framework_elements.name: Design for recycling
framework_elements.description: Designing products to remove any barriers to recycling and enable easy recyclability

framework_elements.name: Sensors, monitoring systems
framework_elements.description: Installing sensors to gather data from products and services to identify, enable and/or implement circular strategies (eg. effective resource use & logistics planning, circular business models & design)

framework_elements.name: Design for reuse
framework_elements.description: Designing products to be reused for the same or different purposes in multiple lifecycles

framework_elements.name: Closed loop downcycling
framework_elements.description: Transforming waste products into materials and lower value products within the same industry

framework_elements.name: Advanced robotics, artificial intelligence
framework_elements.description: Employing artificial algorithms and robotics to identify, enable and/or implement circular strategies (eg. effective resource use & logistics planning, circular business models & design)

framework_elements.name: Strengthen and advance knowledge
framework_elements.description: Develop research, structure knowledge, encourage innovation networks and disseminate findings with integrity

framework_elements.name: Service business models
framework_elements.description: Deliver services through business models that ensure maximum value

framework_elements.name: Reduce Energy Consumption
framework_elements.description: Reduced use of fossil fuel energy sources and/or increased use of renewable energy

framework_elements.name: Revenue Potential
framework_elements.description: Direct and indirect effects that increase revenues or the potential for new revenues, for example from new products, customer segments, partnerships or business models

framework_elements.name: Reduce Material Consumption (SDG12)
framework_elements.description: Reduced use of virgin materials and/or an increase of the use of secondary and bio-based materials

framework_elements.name: Social Impact
framework_elements.description: Impacts on the social fabric of the community and well-being of the individuals and families.

framework_elements.name: Equality
framework_elements.description: Contribution to social parity, or impact on social disparity

framework_elements.name: Well-being
framework_elements.description: Impact on the health and happiness of human populations

framework_elements.name: Innovation
framework_elements.description: Impact on the ease of innovation, and facilitating uptake of innovations

framework_elements.name: Biodiversity
framework_elements.description: Contributing to the improvement of biodiversity including species diversity, total number of protected species, and ecosystem health

framework_elements.name: Increase Awareness
framework_elements.description: Impact on increased knowledge and understanding as a result of the case study

framework_elements.name: Economic Impact
framework_elements.description: Impacts on the financial condition of a company, as well as the the economicconditions of its stakeholders and on economic systems at local, national, andglobal levels.

framework_elements.name: Cost Savings
framework_elements.description: Direct and indirect reduction in economic costs

framework_elements.name: Jobs
framework_elements.description: Impact on the quantity or quality of jobs, and shifts in the labour market

framework_elements.name: Ecological Impact
framework_elements.description: Impact on the availability of resources as well as their effect on living organisms, ecosystems, and components of the environment.

framework_elements.name: Save Water (SDG6)
framework_elements.description: Reduced use and withdrawal of water and rate of recycling and reuse of water

framework_elements.name: Reduce Emissions (SDG13)
framework_elements.description: Reduced green house gas emissions released into the biosphere

framework_elements.name: Minimise Waste (SDG12)
framework_elements.description:
Minimise waste through diversion: Instead of sending waste to landfill, it is redirected into other industrial processes for handling, treatment, recycling, recovery, or reuse in various forms. 

Minimise waste through design: At the outset of a process of project, plan and design such that there is zero waste or minimal waste during production, use, and at end of life.

framework_elements.name: Scalability
framework_elements.description: Solutions that can be applied at scale

framework_elements.name: Productivity
framework_elements.description: Efficiency gains on operations or transactions either through cultural or technological shifts

framework_elements.name: Mining
framework_elements.description: Extracting resources and minerals from the earth, such as coal, oil, gas, iron, bauxite, sand, clay, etc.

framework_elements.name: Logistics Services
framework_elements.description: Providing air, water, rail, and land transportation and related services for the distribution of goods, such as air freight, air courier and logistics services, maritime freight, marine courier and logistics services, rail freight, rail courier and logistics services, land freight, land courier and logistics services, including package and mail delivery and customs agents, as well as storage and warehouse facilities

framework_elements.name: Consumable Fuels
framework_elements.description: Producing and refining oil, gas, and other consumable fuels related to the generation of energy

framework_elements.name: Transportation Equipment
framework_elements.description: Producing transportation equipment for the movement of goods and people by air, rail, sea, and land, including airplanes, spacecraft and military equipment, ships, boats, rail locomotives and rolling stock, motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers, and related equipment, as well as repair services for such equipment

framework_elements.name: Personal Products and Services
framework_elements.description: Producing and providing leisure and personal products and services for consumers, such as cleaning products, sports equipment and toys, personal and beauty care products, as well as domestic and personal services such as caretaking, cleaning, hairdressing and other beauty treatment, funeral and related activities

framework_elements.name: Home and Office Furnishings
framework_elements.description: Producing indoor products for the home and office, such as furniture, including upholstery, carpets and wall-coverings, as well as cutlery, cookware, glassware, crystal, silverware, utensils, kitchenware and household specialties

framework_elements.name: Metal and Glass
framework_elements.description: Refining and processing ores and producing ferrous and non-ferrous metal and glass products, including packaging

framework_elements.name: Water and Sewage
framework_elements.description: Providing water and sewage services, including water collection and distribution, water treatment systems and sewage treatment facilities

framework_elements.name: Agri/Food
framework_elements.description: Producing agricultural products and processing them into food and beverageproducts for consumption

framework_elements.name: Materials and Fuels
framework_elements.description: Extracting resources and processing them to produce materials for use bysociety

framework_elements.name: Waste Management
framework_elements.description: Collecting waste from households and businesses by means of refuse bins, wheeled bins, containers, etc., and providing treatment, incineration, materials recovery and reclamation, and disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous waste

framework_elements.name: Chemical and Plastic
framework_elements.description: Producing basic and specialty chemicals, inks, agricultural chemical such as fertilisers and pesticides, plastics including packaging, and rubber

framework_elements.name: Creative Services
framework_elements.description: Producing and providing services that utilise the creative talent of individuals to generate intellectual property, including movies and television shows, music, live performances, advertising, marketing or public relations services, newspapers, magazines and books, and commercial printing services

framework_elements.name: Construction and Infrastructure
framework_elements.description: Producing building materials and providing services to create residential and non-residential infrastructure and real estate

framework_elements.name: Software and Communications
framework_elements.description: Operating networks and software that enable the exchange and broadcasting of information, such as entertainment and internet software, television, cable, satellite or radio broadcasting systems, and cellular, wireless and/or fixed-line telecommunications services

framework_elements.name: Hospitality and Tourism
framework_elements.description: Providing recreational and cultural services, including hotels, resorts, casinos, sport and fitness centers, stadiums, golf courses and amusement parks, restaurants, bars, pubs, fast-food or take-out facilities, as well as libraries and museums

framework_elements.name: Professional Services
framework_elements.description: Providing specialist services to support consumers, businesses, andgovernments

framework_elements.name: Wood and Paper
framework_elements.description: Extracting and gathering wood through forestry and producing wood and paper products

framework_elements.name: Healthcare Services
framework_elements.description: Providing healthcare services, such as hospitals, medical facilities and patient care services, medical research and clinical trial services, pharmaceuticals and drug development, and genetic engineering services

framework_elements.name: Transportation and Logistics
framework_elements.description: Producing transporation equipment and providing services for thetransportation of goods and people

framework_elements.name: Fashion and Textiles
framework_elements.description: Producing textile and leather products and processing them into apparel and accessories

framework_elements.name: Machinery
framework_elements.description: Producing machinery for mining, construction, industrial, and agricultural use, such as heavy duty trucks, rolling machinery, earth-moving and construction equipment, farm machinery, commercial printing and presses, machine tools, compressors, pollution control equipment, elevators, escalators, insulators, pumps, etc., including their related parts

framework_elements.name: Passenger Transport Services
framework_elements.description: Providing air, water, rail, and land transportation for passengers, such as airlines, airports, ferries, cruise-ships, tour boat operators, marine ports, railways, train stations, tour bus operators, vehicle rental, and taxi companies, travel agencies and related services

framework_elements.name: Research & Commercial Services
framework_elements.description: Providing various support services for businesses and governments, such as research, testing, certification and consulting services, cleaning and maintenance services, security and protection services, legal, accounting and bookkeeping services, information management, data processing, and business process outsourcing services

framework_elements.name: Food and Beverage
framework_elements.description: Processing and producing food and beverages for consumption

framework_elements.name: Energy Utilities and Independent Power Producers
framework_elements.description: Providing electricity and gas services, including traditional and renewable energy generation, natural and manufactured gas and operating gas networks

framework_elements.name: Societal Services
framework_elements.description: Providing general societal services

framework_elements.name: Financial Services
framework_elements.description: Providing commercial and consumer financial services, such as lending, credit, financing, banking, asset management, financial exchanges, ratings services, money services, insurance and pension services, etc.

framework_elements.name: Goods and Services
framework_elements.description: Producing and providing business and consumer goods and services

framework_elements.name: Construction and Real Estate Services
framework_elements.description: Providing residential and non-residential construction services, such as architectural, engineering, planning, real-estate, contracting, and inspection services

framework_elements.name: Agriculture
framework_elements.description: Producing and gathering crop and animal products from land and water through farming, hunting, and fishing

framework_elements.name: Education and Government Services
framework_elements.description: Providing public and private education and support services at any level or for any profession, and governmental and public administration services, including judicial, regulatory, and legislative activities, taxation, defence, public order and safety, immigration services, foreign affairs and the administration of government programmes

framework_elements.name: Construction Materials and Products
framework_elements.description: Producing building materials and finished and semi-finished building products for construction

framework_elements.name: Electronics and Appliances
framework_elements.description: Producing electronics products for businesses and consumers, including cellular phones, personal computers, printers, servers, electronic computer components and peripherals, TVs, audio equipment, as well as household appliances, such as refrigerators, washing machines, etc.

framework_elements.name: Retail
framework_elements.description: Providing goods on the Internet, through mail order, or television, or providing goods in stores, including apparel, electronics, furniture, food and drug, etc.

framework_elements.name: Electrical and Electronic Equipment
framework_elements.description: Producing electric cables and wires, power-generating equipment, including solar modules, motors, power turbines, as well as electronic equipment and instruments, including computer chips, communication equipment, analytical instruments, lasers, display screens, point-of-sales machines, security system equipment, and healthcare equipment

framework_elements.name: Capital Equipment
framework_elements.description: Producing electrical equipment and machinery for industrial use

framework_elements.name: Animal Products
framework_elements.description: Animal products refers to wild fish catch, aquatic plants/animals, hunting and gathering, live animals, animal products and food products like meat, fibre, milk, eggs, or other products.

framework_elements.name: Ferrous metals
framework_elements.description:
Ferrous metals contain iron, whereas non-ferrous metals do not. Ferrous metals are easily identified by their magnetic properties, as well as their poor resistance to corrosion and rust. Typical examples include engineered materials such as steel and cast iron, combining an iron base with small amounts of other metals or elements added in.  (1)


(1) https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/engineering/ferrous-metal

framework_elements.name: Wood
framework_elements.description: Wood is a porous and fibrous structural tissue found in the stems and roots of trees and other woody plants. It is an organic material - a natural composite of cellulose fibers that are strong in tension and embedded in a matrix of lignin, which resists compression.

framework_elements.name: Liquids and gases
framework_elements.description: Refers to 1) crude oils, 2) gas and 3) fuels. They are liquid and gaseous energy materials/carriers. 1) Crude oil is a naturally occurring, unrefined petroleum product composed of hydrocarbon deposits and other organic materials. Crude oil can be refined to produce usable products such as gasoline, diesel and various forms of petrochemicals. 2) Natural gas (also called fossil gas) is a naturally occurring hydrocarbon gas mixture consisting primarily of methane, but commonly including varying amounts of other higher alkanes, and sometimes a small percentage of carbon dioxide, nitrogen, hydrogen sulfide, or helium. Gas is a non-renewable hydrocarbon used as a source of energy for heating, cooking, electricity generation and as a fuel for vehicles. 3) A fuel is any material that can be made to react with other substances so that it releases energy as heat energy or to be used for work, which can be crude oils and gas products, but could for example also be nuclear energy.

framework_elements.name: Construction Dominant
framework_elements.description: This category consists of a number of minerals that are primarily used in construction, and make up the majority of non-metallic minerals extracted today. They contain sand, gravel, and structural clay, which are used in load-bearing structural components, and are often locally sourced and of low economic value. Sand and gravel consist of an unconsolidated accumulation of rounded or semi-rounded rock fragments that result from the natural disintegration of rock; clay is a finely-grained natural rock or soil material that combines one or more clay minerals with possible traces of quartz, metal oxides and organic matter. They also contain limestone and gypsum. Limestone is a carbonate sedimentary rock whose major materials are different crystal forms of calcium carbonate. Gypsum is a soft sulfate mineral composed of calcium sulfate dihydrate. It is widely mined and used as the main constituent in many forms of plaster, blackboard/sidewalk chalk, and drywall. Finally, they contain a number of ornamental and building stones, which can be a variety of minerals that are used for direct building use, rather than as an input for a construction material (e.g. limestone blocks used to make a wall).

framework_elements.name: Crop Residues
framework_elements.description: The residual biomass that is discarded during production, such as straw and leaves, are not included in annual crop statistics. Nevertheless, those crop residues are often subject to further economic use. For example, a large fraction of crop residues is used as bedding material in livestock husbandry; crop residues may also be used as feed, for energy production, or as industrial raw material.

framework_elements.name: Coal and solids
framework_elements.description: Solid fuel refers to various forms of solid material that can be burnt to release energy, providing heat and light through the process of combustion. This includes lignite, hard coal, tar sands, and peat.

framework_elements.name: Industrial / Agricultural Dominant
framework_elements.description:
Industrial and agricultural minerals are non-metallic minerals that are primarily used in chemical, industrial, or agricultural processes. Chemical minerals are used in chemical processes such as the production of detergents, animal feedstock, and many other minor applications. They also contain some applications of salt, which may be produced from rock salt, brine or seawater; it is used for human consumption, in the chemical industry, or to ‘grit’ roads to prevent the formation of ice. Fertiliser minerals are nitrogen, potassium and phosphate, the three most common nutrients used in agriculture. Nitrogen (N), phosphate (P), and potassium (K) are also combined to form NPK compound fertilisers, which provides crops with these nutrients at the same time. 
Finally, there are a number of minerals used as inputs for specific processes: Graphite, a stable form of pure carbon, is mainly used in refractories; Quartz and quartzite are special qualities of silicon used e.g. in the optical industry or in metal manufacturing; Siliceous fossil meals such as Kieselgur, Tripolite, Diatomite and other siliceous earths, used e.g. as absorption agent or material for heat insulation; Steatite and talc are magnesium silicate minerals, used for several industrial purposes; Feldspar is an essential component of glass and ceramic manufacture.

framework_elements.name: Minerals & chemicals
framework_elements.description:
What is it?
A mineral is, broadly speaking, a solid chemical compound that occurs naturally in pure form. Minerals are most commonly associated with rocks due to the presence of minerals within rocks. These rocks may consist of one type of mineral, or may be an aggregate of two or more different types of minerals. Non-metallic minerals are those which do not yield new products on melting. The materials include minerals that do not contain metals or fossil energy carriers. Examples of non-metallic minerals are; stone, sand, clay, and salt.
How is it produced?
Non-metallic minerals are extracted from the environment through mining and quarrying activities, or via dredging of alluvial deposits, rock crushing and the use of salt marshes.
Where/how is it used in our economy (main sectors, main products, ingredients)?
Non-metallic minerals (2) are used most notably in construction (e.g. sands, gravel, stones etc.), manufacture of mineral products (e.g. glass, cement etc.), or manufacture of chemicals (e.g. mineral fertilisers).
Why should we care from a circular economy perspective? (How is it un-circular?)
Mineral mining and processing activities can be highly destructive to local ecosystems. Mining of non-metallic minerals can have negative environmental impacts on air, water, and soil. Stone dust produced from crusher units can also be damaging for human health (3). Mitigating the environmental impacts of industrial mineral mines could be improved by changes to existing regulations and by implementing circular approaches such as lifetime extension, remanufacturing, and reuse.
(1) https://www.slideshare.net/hzharraz/nonmetallic-mineral-deposits#:~:targetText=Non%2Dmetallic%20minerals%20are%20those,associated%20with%20igneous%2Fmetamorphic%20rocks.
(2) MF.3
(3) https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10106049.2019.1597390?journalCode=tgei20

framework_elements.name: Biomass
framework_elements.description:
What is it?
Biomass is the biodegradable fraction of products, waste and residues of biological origin from agriculture (including vegetal and animal substances), forestry, fisheries and aquaculture, as well as the biodegradable fraction of industrial and municipal waste. Includes bioliquids and biofuels. (1)
How is it produced?
Biomass is generated through the biocycle. (2) The cycling of nutrients is critical for the growth of all plant and animal life on the planet. At its most basic level, the natural cycle sees nutrients such as nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium absorbed from the soil by plants, which are then consumed by animals (including humans). These nutrients are subsequently excreted and returned to the soil, where plants can take them in again. Throughout the biocycle, biomass absorbs CO2 from the atmosphere while growing. This effect can be magnified when these materials are subsequently reused or recycled. (3)
Where/how is it used in our economy (main sectors, main products, ingredients)?
Every year, people harvest roughly 13 billion tonnes of biomass globally to use as food, energy and materials. Biomass accounts for roughly 9% of world total primary energy supply today. (4) Additionally, cities produce about 650 million tonnes of solid organic waste per year. (5)
Why should we care from a circular economy perspective?
Biomass use is confronted with some dilemmas, such as the use of biomass as an energy source by means of combustion or fermentation, versus a more high-value application (e.g. the processing of residual wood for furniture). For every application, the highest value must be recovered. A general rule of thumb is that the fewer process steps a material has to go through for reuse, the higher the quality of the material it can contain. This means that it is important to direct the use of renewable materials to applications where they contribute the most to sustainability.
(1) Source: https://www.ellenmacarthurfoundation.org/assets/downloads/publications/Urban-Biocycles_Ellen-MacArthurFoundation_30-3-2017.pdf
(2) Source: https://stats.oecd.org/glossary/detail.asp?ID=201
(3) Source: https://www.ellenmacarthurfoundation.org/assets/galleries/ce100/CE100-Renewables_Co.Project_Report.pdf
(4) Source: https://www.iea.org/topics/renewables/bioenergy/
(5) Source: https://www.ellenmacarthurfoundation.org/assets/downloads/publications/Urban-Biocycles_Ellen-MacArthurFoundation_30-3-2017.pdf

framework_elements.name: Metal & ores
framework_elements.description:
What is it?
Metals are chemical elements that are extracted and processed from mineral ores. Metals, such as aluminum, iron, zinc, gold, silver, tin, and mercury represent a significant fraction of total material flows in the economy.
How is it produced?
Metals are elementary substances extracted from mineral ores. Ores are extracted from the environment through mining and quarrying activities. Metlas can be extracted from the ore by three main methods: reduction of the ore with carbon, reduction of the molten ore by electrolysis, and reduction of the ore with a more reactive metal (1). The process of refining uses a significant amount of energy, and consequently produces a large carbon footprint.
Where/how is it used in our economy (main sectors, main products, ingredients)?
Metals are omnipresent in common products across industries due to their wide range of functionalities and performance characteristics. Metals are essential for many of our product production processes. Over the 20th century demand has risen steeply, and this is expected to continue over the next decades. The UN Environment Programme (UNEP) calculated that low-carbon technologies would need over 600 million tonnes (Mt) more metal resources up to 2050 (2). Alongside the usual suspects of cobalt, lithium and rare-earth-metals, this includes aluminium, silver, steel, nickel, lead and zinc.
Why should we care from a circular economy perspective? (How is it un-circular?)
- Mining is energy and carbon intensive (3) - Scarce metals are mismanaged and are associated with social impacts (conflict minerals) - Given their recyclability and durability, circular economy solutions are a top priority.
(1) https://revisionscience.com/a2-level-level-revision/chemistry-level-revision/bonding-and-structure/reduction-metals-extraction-ore#:~:targetText=There%20are%203%20main%20methods,with%20a%20more%20reactive%20metal.
(2) https://www.carbonbrief.org/explainer-these-six-metals-are-key-to-a-low-carbon-future
(3) Tost, M., Bayer, B., Hitch, M., Lutter, S., Moser, P., & Feiel, S. (2018). Metal Mining’s Environmental Pressures: A Review and Updated Estimates on CO2 Emissions, Water Use, and Land Requirements. Sustainability, 10(8), 2881.

framework_elements.name: Non ferrous metals
framework_elements.description: Non ferrous metals do not contain iron. Some examples of non-ferrous metals are aluminum, aluminum alloys, and copper, which are often used in industrial applications such as gutters, roofing, pipes, and electrical. Non-ferrous metals also include brass, gold, nickel, silver, tin, lead, and zinc.

framework_elements.name: Crops
framework_elements.description: A crop is a plant or animal product that can be grown and harvested extensively for profit or subsistence. Crop may refer either to the harvested parts or to the harvest in a more refined state. Most crops are cultivated in agriculture or aquaculture. Some examples are: cereals, dry pulses, protein crops, root crops, industrial crops, fresh vegetables and permanent crops.

framework_elements.name: Fossil carriers
framework_elements.description:
What is it?
Fossil energy carriers are non-renewable materials, which include coal, oil, and natural gas. These fossil carriers contain energy that can be later converted to other forms such as mechanical work or heat or to operate chemical or physical processes.
How is it produced?
Domestic extraction of fossil energy carriers (solid, liquid and gaseous) takes place through underground or open-cast mining, and the operation of crude oil and natural gas fields.
Where/how is it used in our economy (main sectors, main products, ingredients)?
Fossil fuel carriers are primarily used to provide electricity, heat, and transportation. They supply about 80 percent of the world’s energy and also feed the processes used to produce a wide range of products, from steel to plastics.
Why should we care from a circular economy perspective? (How is it un-circular?)
Carbon dioxide emissions from burning coal are the biggest single source of global temperature increase above pre-industrial levels, and account for 44% of the world's total emissions. Governments around the world are now engaged in efforts to ramp down greenhouse gas emissions generated from fossil fuels. These efforts generally focus on replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy sources, increasing energy efficiency, and electrifying sectors such as transportation and buildings. However, many city governments lack the ability to directly control the energy mix of their electricity, as policies are often set at state or national levels. Despite such challenges, some major cities are showing that it is possible to reduce fossil fuel usage. This year, over 300 cities joined in CDP’s cities programme, sharing information on how they are taking actions to reduce carbon emissions and managing climate risks (1).
(1) https://www.cdp.net/en/cities

framework_elements.name: Circular use of public-owned assets (land, buildings and equipment)
Regulate
framework_elements.description: 'Regulate' changes the rules of the systems to achieve compliance through enforcement.

framework_elements.name: Metrics and indicators to measure progress
Develop infrastructure to support sustainable lifestyles
Develop infrastructure to support resource cycling
Site planning for circular material use
Manage
framework_elements.description: 'Manage' influences the use and function of physical and material elements within the urban environment.

framework_elements.name: Incentivise
framework_elements.description: 'Incentivise' sends market signals and support to businesses, citizens and governments to promote certain activities.

framework_elements.name: Inform
framework_elements.description: 'Inform' increases the overall levels of awareness and builds the necessary skills and knowledge around the circular economy to foster long-term change.

framework_elements.name: Mobilise
framework_elements.description: 'Mobilise' sets the direction of and builds momentum towards long-term change, while also determining how this direction is determined and governed.

framework_elements.name: Develop circular criteria for public procurement of assets
